content.prompt:
â€‹

  • All coordinates are approximate.
  • Moving from left to right:
    • The curve begins at point (negative 5 comma negative 4).
    • The curve increases to a maximum at point (negative 3 comma 4).
    • The curve decreases to a minimum point at (negative 1 comma negative 4).
    • The curve increases to a maximum point at (1 comma 4).
    • The curve decreases to a minimum point at (3 comma negative 4).
    • The curve increases and ends at point (5 comma 4).

The graph of the function f{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"} is given in the xy{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}-plane. Which of the following functions has the same period as f{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"} ?

choices.label:
• All coordinates are approximate.
  • Moving from left to right:
    • The curve begins at point (negative 5 comma 3).
    • The curve decreases to a minimum at point (negative 2.5 comma negative 4).
    • The curve increases to a maximum point at  (0.5 comma 4).
    • The curve decreases to a minimum point at  (3.5 comma negative 4).
    • The curve increases and ends at point (5 comma 0).

assistive_label.label: Figure for Option A. Refer to its long description

• All coordinates are approximate.
  • Moving from left to right:

    • The curve increases to a maximum at point (negative 3.5 comma 2).
    • The curve decreases to a minimum at point (negative 2.5 comma negative 2).
    • The curve increases to a maximum at point (negative 1.5 comma 2).
    • The curve decreases to a minimum at point (negative 0.5 comma negative 2).
    • The curve increases to a maximum at point (0.5 comma 2).
    • The curve decreases to a minimum at point (1.5 comma negative 2).
    • The curve increases to a maximum at point (2.5 comma 2).
    • The curve decreases to a minimum at point (3.5 comma negative 2).
    • The curve increases to a maximum at point (4.5 comma 2).
    • The curve decreases and ends at point (5 comma 0).

skill.text: Skill 2.B: Construct equivalent graphical, numerical, analytical, and verbal representations of functions that are useful in a given mathematical or applied context, with and without technology.
